title: What’s in your makeup drawer
body: An Essay on Typography by Eric Gill takes the reader back to the year 1930. The year when a conflict between two worlds came to its term. The machines of the industrial world finally took over the handicrafts.

The typography of this industrial age was no longer handcrafted. Mass production and profit became more important. Quantity mattered more than the quality. The books and printed works in general lost a part of its humanity. The typefaces were not produced by craftsmen anymore. It was the machines printing and tying the books together now. The craftsmen had to let go of their craft and became a cog in the process. An extension of the industrial machine.

But the victory of the industrialism didn’t mean that the craftsmen were completely extinct. The two worlds continued to coexist independently. Each recognising the good in the other — the power of industrialism and the humanity of craftsmanship. This was the second transition that would strip typography of a part of its humanity. We have to go 500 years back in time to meet the first one.

A similar conflict emerged after the invention of the first printing press in Europe. Johannes Gutenberg invented movable type and used it to produce different compositions. His workshop could print up to 240 impressions per hour. Until then, the books were being copied by hand. All the books were handwritten and decorated with hand drawn ornaments and figures. A process of copying a book was long but each book, even a copy, was a work of art.

Human beings aren’t perfect. Perfection is something that will always elude us. There will always be a small part of humanity in everything we do. No matter how small that part, we should make sure that it transcends the limits of the medium. We have to think about the message first. What typeface should we use and why? Does the typeface match the message and what we want to communicate with it? What will be the leading and why? Will there be more typefaces in our design? On what ground will they be combined? What makes our design unique and why? This is the part of humanity that is left in typography. It might be the last part. Are we really going to give it up?

title: Elegance is when the inside is as beautiful as the outside
body: What we eat, how we move, and how we rest are all components of a beautiful life.
The pursuit of perfection in appearance often hides the imperfections that make us human.
Skincare and self-care are no longer indulgences, but essential practices in a fast-paced world.
Slowing down helps us appreciate small moments, whether it's applying perfume or taking a walk.
Beauty begins with gratitude, and ends in expression.
Modern life has shifted how we perceive beauty — from aesthetics to deeper values such as authenticity and intention.
Color theory, minimalism, and visual balance all play essential roles in modern lifestyle design.
Technology has allowed us to connect with others around the globe, but has also influenced how we represent ourselves.
Being present is the most attractive quality of all.
True style is about consistency and comfort — not just trends.
Every place has its own rituals and ideas of beauty — travel teaches us humility.
Sustainability in beauty and fashion continues to reshape consumer expectations and brand responsibilities.

title: Simplicity reveals the true essence of style
body: True style is about consistency and comfort — not just trends.
What we eat, how we move, and how we rest are all components of a beautiful life.
Being present is the most attractive quality of all.
Simplicity reveals the true essence of style.
Less is often more.
Minimalism is a path to clarity and freedom.
Careful curation allows quality to shine.
Investing in classic pieces pays off in the long run.
Style is a personal journey, not a destination.
Trends come and go, but authenticity lasts.
